page.text: Asymptotic Accuracy of the Jackknife Variance Estimator for Certain

The literature does not address the accuracy of v
it wrong, conjecturing that the asymptotic variance of v
functionals! However, Theorem 2 of [Ber84] does contain a general formula for the variance of v
which is valid when the functional T has a kind of second-order functional derivative. The theorem
there applies to the trimmed L-functionals we discuss in Section 4, and to many other functionals
besides, but it is hampered by the hypothesis that p have bounded support. We recommend Theorem 2
of [Ber84] for its generality and its revelation of the role of second-order differentiability, but our
particular results cannot be derived from it directly.
The text [ST95, p 43] purports to prove that the asymptotic variance of n
when T is of the form (14), but there is a mistake there. We paraphrase the following definition
from [ST95, p 43]: For probability measures p and q on the line, let ρ(p, q) denote the L
between the cdf ’s of p and q. A functional T : P(R) −→ R is ρ-Lipschitz differentiable at q if

. They go on to assert that smooth trimmed L-functionals are ρ-Lipschitz
differentiable, but this is false (it is not difficult to construct counterexamples).
A close look at the definition of ρ-Lipschitz differentiability leads one to wonder whether there
are any functionals (besides trivial, linear ones) that satisfy the definition. The problem is that q
appears on the left hand side of (7) but not on the right; it is easy to imagine p

One aim of this letter is to emphasize that Var φ

for some reason, the pseudovalues can be used to this end. Once one has already

the sample variance of the squares of the pseudovalues. We prove this, assuming that the functional
is bounded (trimmed L-functionals satisfy these re-
quirements, for instance). This section is an interlude whose results will not be invoked in Sections 3
and 4, the main part of this note.

Suppose that ℓ : (0, 1) −→ R is supported on [α, 1 − α] for some 0 < α < 1/2, and let
denotes the quantile function for p, i.e., P
(s) = min{x : P (x) ≥ s} for 0 < s < 1 where
P denotes the cdf of p. A plug-in estimate for L is called a trimmed L-statistic, or a trimmed linear
combination of quantiles. (It is called trimmed because the restricted support of ℓ discards outliers.)
L-statistics are good for robust estimation of a location parameter.
Now assume that ℓ is continuous. Then L is Hadamard differentiable (and the L-statistics are
asymptotically normal) at all p ∈ P(R) [vdW98, Lemma 22.10]. The functional derivative at p of L,
evaluated at a bounded signed measure m, is
where M (x) = m((−∞, x]). The asymptotic variance of the L-statistics is
